pli-tv-kd6:1.1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.2: At that time the monks were afflicted with autumn illness, and they could not keep down either rice porridge or other food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.3: Because of that they became thin, haggard, and pale, their veins protruding all over their limbs.
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.4: The Buddha saw them and asked Venerable Ānanda
pli-tv-kd6:1.1.5: why they were looking so sickly.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.1: When the Buddha was in seclusion, he considered this and thought,
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.4: “What tonics might I allow the monks that are generally regarded as tonics, would serve the purpose of nourishment, but aren’t considered as substantial food?”
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.7: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.8: that are generally regarded as tonics, serve the purpose of nourishment, but are not considered as substantial food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.2.9: Let me allow them these five tonics, to be received and consumed before midday.”
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.1: In the evening, when the Buddha had come out from seclusion, he gave a teaching and then told the monks what he had thought, adding:
pli-tv-kd6:1.3.11: “I allow these five tonics to be received and consumed before midday.”
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.1: The monks then received and consumed those five tonics before midday.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.2: But even ordinary food did not agree with them, let alone greasy food.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.3: As result of both the autumn illness and the food not agreeing with them, they became even more thin, haggard, and pale.
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.4: The Buddha saw them and asked Venerable Ānanda
pli-tv-kd6:1.4.5: why they were looking even worse.
pli-tv-kd6:1.5.4: The Buddha then gave a teaching, and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:1.5.5: “I allow the five tonics to be received and consumed both before and after midday.”

pli-tv-kd6:9.1.1: At one time Venerable Ānanda’s preceptor, Venerable Belaṭṭhasīsa, had carbuncles,

pli-tv-kd6:15.1.1: At one time Venerable Pilindavaccha, wanting to build a shelter, was having a hillside cleared near Rājagaha.
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.2: On that occasion King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.4: “Venerable Elder, what are you having made?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.5: “I’m clearing the hillside, great king, because I want to build a shelter.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.1.8: “Well then, Venerable, please ask the Buddha and tell me the outcome.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.1: And Pilindavaccha instructed, inspired, and gladdened King Bimbisāra with a teaching,
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.2: after which the King got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated Pilindavaccha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.3: Soon afterwards Pilindavaccha sent a message to the Buddha:
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.4: “Venerable Sir, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha wishes to provide a monastery worker.
pli-tv-kd6:15.2.6: The Buddha then gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.1: Once again King Bimbisāra went to Pilindavaccha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.3: “Venerable, has the Buddha allowed monastery workers?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.5: “Well then, I’ll provide you with a monastery worker.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.6: But after making this promise, he forgot, and only remembered after a long time. He then addressed the official in charge of all practical affairs:
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.7: “Listen, has that monastery worker I promised been provided?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.3.9: “How long is it since we made that promise?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.1: The official counted the days and said,
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.3: “Well then, provide him with five hundred monastery workers.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.5: The official provided Pilindavaccha with five hundred monastery workers and a separate village was established.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.6: They called it “The Monastery Workers’ Village” and “Pilinda Village”.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.7: And Pilindavaccha began associating with the families in that village.
pli-tv-kd6:15.4.8: After robing up one morning, he took his bowl and robe and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.1: At that time they were holding a celebration in that village,
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.2: and the children were dressed up with ornaments and garlands.
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.3: As Pilindavaccha was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of a certain monastery worker, where he sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.4: Just then the daughter of the house had seen the other children dressed up in ornaments and garlands, and she cried,
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.5: “Give me a garland! Give me ornaments!”
pli-tv-kd6:15.5.10: adding, “How can poor people like us afford garlands and ornaments?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.1: Pilindavaccha took a pad of grass and said to the mother,
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.2: “Here, place this pad of grass on the girl’s head.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.4: and it turned into a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-kd6:15.6.5: Even the royal compound had nothing like it.

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.9: So how did those poor people get it?

pli-tv-kd6:15.6.11: And King Bimbisāra had that family imprisoned.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.1: Once again Pilindavaccha robed up in morning, took his bowl and robe, and entered Pilinda Village for almsfood.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.2: As he was walking on continuous almsround, he came to the house of that monastery worker. And he asked the neighbors,
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.3: “Where is the family of this monastery worker?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.4: “Venerable, the king had them imprisoned because of that golden garland.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.5: Pilindavaccha then went to King Bimbisāra’s house and sat down on a prepared seat.
pli-tv-kd6:15.7.6: King Bimbisāra approached Pilindavaccha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.1: “Great king, why have you had the family of that monastery worker imprisoned?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.2: “Venerable, in the house of that monastery worker there was a beautiful golden garland.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.3: Even the royal compound has nothing like it.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.4: So how did those poor people get it?
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.5: No doubt it was taken by theft.”
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.6: Pilindavaccha then focused his mind on turning King Bimbisāra’s stilt house into gold.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.7: As a result the whole house became gold.
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.8: And he said, “Great king, how did you get so much gold?”
pli-tv-kd6:15.8.9: “Understood, Sir, this is your supernormal power.” And he released that family.
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.2: “It seems Venerable Pilindavaccha has performed a superhuman feat, a wonder of supernormal power, for the king and his court!”
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.3: Being delighted and gaining confidence in Pilindavaccha, they brought him the five tonics:
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.4: ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup.

pli-tv-kd6:15.9.12: When people walking about the dwellings saw this, they complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-kd6:15.9.13: “These Sakyan ascetics are hoarding goods indoors, just like King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha.”

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.4: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Buddha. He had the Sangha gathered and questioned the monks:

pli-tv-kd6:15.10.8: “After being received, the tonics allowable for sick monks—that is, ghee, butter, oil, honey, and syrup—should be used from storage for at most seven days. If you use them beyond that, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Sāvatthī for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Rājagaha.

pli-tv-kd6:16.1.4: and being afraid of wrongdoing, he and his followers did not take sugar.

pli-tv-kd6:30.5.11: “I have already accepted tomorrow’s meal from Ambapālī.”

pli-tv-kd6:30.6.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Koṭigāma as long as he liked, he went to Nātikā,

pli-tv-kd6:30.6.5: And Ambapālī personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, she sat down to one side and said,

pli-tv-kd6:30.6.8: After instructing, inspiring, and gladdening her with a teaching, he got up from his seat and went to the Great Wood near Vesālī,

pli-tv-kd6:31.1.1: On one occasion a number of well-known Licchavīs were seated together in the public hall, praising the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha in many ways.
pli-tv-kd6:31.1.2: Sīha the general, a disciple of the Jains, was seated in that gathering.
pli-tv-kd6:31.1.4: “No doubt that Buddha is perfected, a fully Awakened One, since these well-known Licchavīs praise the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha in this way.
pli-tv-kd6:31.1.5: Let me go and visit that Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.2.1: He then went to Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta and said,
pli-tv-kd6:31.2.2: “Sir, I wish to visit the ascetic Gotama.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.2.3: “Sīha, why visit the ascetic Gotama who teaches non-action when you believe in action?
pli-tv-kd6:31.2.4: For the ascetic Gotama teaches for the sake of non-action, and he trains his disciples in that.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.2.5: And Sīha’s intention to go died down.
pli-tv-kd6:31.3.1: The same sequence of events happened a second time.
pli-tv-kd6:31.3.10: A third time a number of well-known Licchavīs were seated together in the public hall, praising the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha in many ways.
pli-tv-kd6:31.3.11: Sīha heard this, and he had the same thoughts as before.
pli-tv-kd6:31.3.13: In addition he thought this, “What can the Jains do to me, whether I get their permission or not?
pli-tv-kd6:31.3.14: Let me go and visit the Buddha, the Perfected and fully Awakened One, without getting permission from the Jains.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.4.1: Soon afterwards, in the middle of the day, General Sīha set out from Vesālī with five hundred carriages to visit the Buddha.
pli-tv-kd6:31.4.2: He went by chariot as far as the ground would allow, dismounted, and then approached the Buddha on foot. He bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd6:31.4.4: “Sir, I have heard that the ascetic Gotama teaches non-action, that he teaches for the sake of non-action, and that he trains his disciples in that.
pli-tv-kd6:31.4.6: do they say what you have said without falsely misrepresenting you? Do they explain according to the Teaching so that they can’t be legitimately criticized?
pli-tv-kd6:31.4.7: I don’t wish to misrepresent you.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.5.1: “There is a way, Sīha, one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.5.2: that I teach non-action, that I teach for the sake of non-action, and that I train my disciples in that.
pli-tv-kd6:31.6.3: I teach the non-doing of misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
pli-tv-kd6:31.6.4: I teach the non-doing of various kinds of bad and unwholesome actions.
pli-tv-kd6:31.6.7: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.6.8: that I teach action, that I teach for the sake of action, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way
pli-tv-kd6:31.6.9: I teach the doing of good conduct by body, speech, and mind; I teach the doing of various kinds of good and wholesome actions.
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.1: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.2: that I am an annihilationist, that I teach for the sake of annihilation, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.3: I teach the annihilation of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion;
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.4: I teach the annihilation of various kinds of bad and unwholesome actions.
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.7: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.8: that I am detestable, that I teach for the sake of detesting, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.9: I detest misconduct by body, speech, and mind;
pli-tv-kd6:31.7.10: I detest being possessed of various kinds of bad and unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.1: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.2: that I’m an exterminator, that I teach for the sake of extermination, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.3: I teach the extermination of sensual desire, ill will, and confusion,
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.4: the extermination of various kinds of bad and unwholesome qualities.
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.7: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.8: that I’m austere, that I teach for the sake of austerity, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.9: I say that bad, unwholesome qualities—
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.10: misconduct by body, speech, and mind—are to be disciplined.
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.11: One who has abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined, who has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm-stump, done away with them so utterly that they are incapable of reappearing—such a one I call one who is austere.
pli-tv-kd6:31.8.12: Now the Buddha has abandoned the bad, unwholesome qualities that are to be disciplined, has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm tree, done away with them so utterly that they are incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.1: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.2: that I’m withdrawn, that I teach for the sake of withdrawal, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.3: One whose future conception in a womb, whose rebirth in a future life, is abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that one is incapable of reappearing—such a one I call one who is withdrawn.
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.4: Now the Buddha’s future conception in a womb, his rebirth in a future life, is abandoned and cut off at the root, made like a palm-stump, so utterly done away with that he is incapable of reappearing.
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.7: There is a way one could rightly say of me
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.8: that I’m at ease, that I teach for the sake of ease, and that I train my disciples in that. What is that way?
pli-tv-kd6:31.9.9: I’m at ease in the highest sense; I proclaim my Teaching for sake of ease, and I train my disciples in that.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.1: When the Buddha had finished, Sīha exclaimed,
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.2: “Wonderful, Venerable Sir, wonderful! Just as one might set upright what had been overturned, or reveal what was hidden, or show the way to one who was lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what’s there—just so have you made the Teaching clear in many ways. I go for refuge to you and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.3: Please accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.4: “Consider it carefully, Sīha. It’s good for well-known people such as yourself to think carefully.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.5: “Now I’m even more pleased with you, Sir.
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.7: If I became a lay follower of another religion, they would carry a banner all over Vesālī proclaiming it.
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.10: For the second time I go for refuge to you and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:31.10.11: Please accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.1: “For a long time, Sīha, your family has been a wellspring of support for the Jains. When they come to you, you should still consider giving them almsfood.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.2: “Now I’m even more pleased with you, Sir.
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.4: I had heard that you say
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.5: that offerings should only be given to you and your disciples, not to anyone else,
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.6: and that only offerings given to you and your disciples are fruitful, not what’s given to others.
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.7: But in reality you encourage me to give to the Jains.
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.8: Indeed, I shall know the right time for this.
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.9: For the third time I go for refuge to you and to the Teaching and to the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:31.11.10: Please accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.1: The Buddha then gave Sīha a progressive teaching:
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.2: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation. When the Buddha knew that his mind were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path. And just as a clean and stainless cloth takes the dye properly, so too, while he was sitting right there, Sīha experienced the stainless vision of the Truth: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.” He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; he had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction.
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.3: He then said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.4: “Please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.5: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.6: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sīha got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.9: And the following morning Sīha had various kinds of fine food prepared, and he had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:31.12.10: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to General Sīha’s house, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.1: Just then a number of Jains were walking around Vesālī, from street to street, from intersection to intersection, holding up their arms and calling out,
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.2: “General Sīha has killed a large animal and made a meal for the ascetic Gotama. The ascetic Gotama is eating that meat knowing that the animal was killed for his sake.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.3: A certain man approached Sīha and whispered to him what the Jains were doing.
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.6: Sīha said, “Forget about it. For a long time those venerables have disparaged the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.7: They will grow old and still keep on misrepresenting the Buddha with lies.
pli-tv-kd6:31.13.8: And as for me, I would not kill a living being for the sake of my life.”
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.1: Sīha then personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Sīha sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.2: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching. He then got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.4: “You should not eat meat when you know the animal was killed for your sake.
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.5: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd6:31.14.6: I allow you to eat meat and fish that is pure in three respects: you haven’t seen, heard, or suspected that the animal was killed for your sake.”
pli-tv-kd6:32.1.0: The allowance for a food-storage area
pli-tv-kd6:32.1.1: Some time later in Vesālī, there was plenty of food, the crops were abundant, and there was no problem getting by on almsfood.
pli-tv-kd6:32.1.2: Then, while the Buddha was in seclusion, he thought,
pli-tv-kd6:32.1.3: “Those things that I allowed the monks when there was a shortage of food, the crops were meager, and it was hard to get by on almsfood—that is, what has been stored indoors within the monastery, what has been cooked indoors within the monastery, what has been cooked by the monks themselves, what has been received after picking it up, what has been brought out, what has been received before the meal, what has come from the forest or a lotus pond—do the monks still make use of this?”
pli-tv-kd6:32.1.4: When the Buddha had come out from seclusion, he asked Venerable Ānanda about this.
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.2: “Those things that I allowed you when there was a shortage of food, the crops were meager, and it was hard to get by on almsfood, I prohibit from today onward.
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.3: You should not eat what has been stored indoors within the monastery, what has been cooked indoors within the monastery, what has been cooked by yourselves, or what has been received after picking it up.
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.4: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.5: If you have finished your meal and refused an invitation to eat more, you should not eat non-leftovers that have been brought out, that have been received before the meal, or that have come from the forest or a lotus pond.
pli-tv-kd6:32.2.6: If you do, you should be dealt with according to the rule.”
pli-tv-kd6:33.1.1: At that time people from the country loaded much salt, oil, rice, and non-staple food onto carts, brought them to outside the monastery gateway, and waited for their turn to cook a meal.
pli-tv-kd6:33.1.2: Just then a storm was approaching.
pli-tv-kd6:33.1.3: Those people went to Venerable Ānanda and told him what was happening, adding, “What should we do now?”
pli-tv-kd6:33.1.4: Ānanda told the Buddha, who said,
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.1: “Well then, Ānanda, the Sangha should designate a building at the edge of the monastery as a food-storage area and then store the food there—whether it a dwelling, a stilt house, or a cave.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.2: And it should be done like this.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.3: A competent and capable monk should inform the Sangha:
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.4: ‘Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.5: If it seems appropriate to the Sangha, the Sangha should designate such-and-such a dwelling as a food-storage area.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.7: Please, Venerables, I ask the Sangha to listen.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.8: The Sangha designates such-and-such a dwelling as a food-storage area.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.9: Any monk who approves of designating such-and-such a dwelling as a food-storage area should remain silent.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.10: Any monk who does not approve should speak up.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.11: The Sangha has designated such-and-such a dwelling as a food-storage area.
pli-tv-kd6:33.2.12: The Sangha approves and is therefore silent. I will remember it thus.’”
pli-tv-kd6:33.3.1: Soon afterwards people used the agreed-upon food-storage area for various purposes: for cooking rice porridge and rice, to prepare curries, to chop meat, and to split firewood.
pli-tv-kd6:33.3.2: After getting up early in the morning, the Buddha heard loud noises, just like the cawing of crows. He asked Venerable Ānanda what it was,
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.1: and Ānanda explained what was going on.
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.4: “You should not use an agreed-upon food-storage area.
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.5: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.6: I allow three places as food-storage areas:
pli-tv-kd6:33.4.7: a building made according to a proclamation, a place where cows rest, and a place given for the purpose by a householder.”
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.1: Soon afterwards Venerable Yasoja was sick.
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.3: and the monks stored them outside.
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.4: Vermin ate them and thieves stole them.
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.6: “I allow you to use an agreed-upon food-storage area.

pli-tv-kd6:33.5.8: a building made according to a proclamation, a building where cows rest, a building given for the purpose by a householder, and a building agreed upon by the Sangha.”
pli-tv-kd6:33.5.9: The fourth section for recitation on Sīha is finished.
pli-tv-kd6:34.1.0: The account of the householder Meṇḍaka

pli-tv-kd6:34.1.3: He would wash his hair, sweep out his granary, and sit down outside the door. A shower of grain would then fall out of the sky and fill his granary.
pli-tv-kd6:34.1.4: His wife, too, had supernormal powers.

pli-tv-kd6:34.13.10: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:34.14.1: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Meṇḍaka got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.14.2: The following morning Meṇḍaka had various kinds of fine food prepared, and he had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:34.14.3: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to Meṇḍaka’s house, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:34.15.1: Then Meṇḍaka’s wife, son, daughter-in-law, and slave approached the Buddha, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd6:34.15.2: And the Buddha gave them a progressive teaching,
pli-tv-kd6:34.15.3: just as he had done to Meṇḍaka. They, too, experienced the stainless vision of the Truth,
pli-tv-kd6:34.15.4: and they expressed their appreciation in the same way
pli-tv-kd6:34.16.1: Meṇḍaka then personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Meṇḍaka sat down to one side and said,
pli-tv-kd6:34.16.2: “Sir, as long as you’re staying in Bhaddiya, I would like to offer a regular meal to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.16.3: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.0: The allowance for five products of a cow, etc.
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Bhaddiya for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Aṅguttarāpa with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks. He had not taken leave of Meṇḍaka,
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.2: but when Meṇḍaka heard about it,
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.4: he told his slaves and workers,
pli-tv-kd6:34.17.5: “Load lots of salt, oil, rice, and non-staples onto the carts, and bring along twelve-hundred and fifty cowherds and twelve-hundred and fifty dairy cows. We’ll give the Buddha fresh milk wherever we see him.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.1: Meṇḍaka caught up with the Buddha while he was traversing a wilderness area.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.2: Meṇḍaka approached the Buddha, bowed down,
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.4: “Sir, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.5: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.6: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Meṇḍaka bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with his right side toward him, and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.18.7: The following morning Meṇḍaka had various kinds of fine food prepared and then had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.1: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to Meṇḍaka’s meal offering, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.2: Meṇḍaka then told the twelve-hundred and fifty cowherds,
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.3: “Listen, bring one cow for each and every monk and give them fresh milk.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.4: Meṇḍaka then personally served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha and he gave them fresh milk.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.5: Being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not accept.
pli-tv-kd6:34.19.6: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.1: When the Buddha had finished his meal, Meṇḍaka sat down to one side,
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.3: “Sir, there are wilderness roads where there is little water and little food, where it’s not easy to travel without provisions.
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.4: It would be good, Sir, if you would allow provisions.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.20.5: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened Meṇḍaka with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.3: milk, curd, buttermilk, butter, and ghee.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.4: There are wilderness roads where there is little water and little food, where it’s not easy to travel without provisions.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.5: I allow you to look for provisions: whatever you need of rice, mung beans, black gram, salt, sugar, oil, and ghee.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.6: There are people who have faith and confidence. They may deposit money with an attendant, saying,
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.7: “With this, please get what is allowable for the venerable.”
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.8: I allow you to consent to what is allowable from that fund.
pli-tv-kd6:34.21.9: But I say that under no circumstances should you look for or consent to gold, silver, or money.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.0: The account of Keṇiya the dreadlocked ascetic
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.1: Wandering on, the Buddha eventually arrived at Āpaṇa.
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.3: “The ascetic Gotama, the Sakyan, who has gone forth from the Sakyan clan, has arrived at Āpaṇa.” And he heard about the Buddha’s qualities just as Meṇḍaka had.
pli-tv-kd6:35.1.6: “What should I take to the ascetic Gotama?”
pli-tv-kd6:35.2.2: “There are those ancient sages of the brahmins, the creators and teachers of the Vedas,
pli-tv-kd6:35.2.3: that is, Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamataggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu. The brahmins at present still sing and proclaim the ancient verses that they sang, proclaimed, and collected. Now those ancient sages abstained from eating at night and at the wrong time, yet they consented to certain drinks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.1: The ascetic Gotama also abstains from eating at night and at the wrong time, and it would be appropriate for him to consent to the same drinks.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.2: He then had a large quantity of drinks prepared. Lifting them with carrying poles, he went to the Buddha. He exchanged pleasantries with the Buddha
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.6: “Please give them to the monks, Keṇiya.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.8: but being afraid of wrongdoing, the monks did not receive them.
pli-tv-kd6:35.3.9: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.1: Keṇiya then personally served that large quantity of drinks to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Keṇiya sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.2: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching,
pli-tv-kd6:35.4.4: “Good Gotama, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the Sangha of monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.1: “The Sangha is large, Keṇiya. There are twelve hundred and fifty monks. Moreover, you have confidence in the brahmins.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.2: Keṇiya acknowledged what the Buddha had said,
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.3: but repeated his invitation a second time.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.5: and Keṇiya repeated his invitation a third time.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.7: The Buddha then consented by remaining silent.
pli-tv-kd6:35.5.8: Knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.1: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.3: mango drinks, rose-apple drinks, drinks from bananas with seeds, drinks from seedless bananas, licorice drinks, grape drinks, drinks made from lotus tubers, falsa fruit drinks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.4: I allow juice from all fruits, except grain.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.5: I allow juice from all leaves, except the leaves of potherb.
pli-tv-kd6:35.6.6: I allow juice from all flowers, except licorice flowers.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.1: The following morning Keṇiya had various kinds of fine food prepared in his own hermitage, and he had the Buddha informed that the meal was ready.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.2: After robing up, the Buddha took his bowl and robe and went to Keṇiya’s hermitage, where he sat down on the prepared seat together with the Sangha of monks.
pli-tv-kd6:35.7.3: Keṇiya then served various kinds of fine food to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Keṇiya sat down to one side,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.1: and the Buddha expressed his appreciation with these verses:
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.4: A king is the best of humans,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.5: The ocean the chief of rivers.
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.6: The moon is the best in the night sky,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.7: The sun the best of all that shines.
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.8: But for those making offerings, desiring merit,
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.9: The Sangha is indeed the best.”
pli-tv-kd6:35.8.10: And the Buddha got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.0: The account of Roja the Mallian
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Āpaṇa for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Kusinārā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.2: When the Mallians of Kusinārā heard that the Buddha was coming,
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.3: they made an agreement that whoever did not go out to meet the Buddha would be fined five hundred coins.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.4: At that time Venerable Ānanda had a friend called Roja the Mallian.
pli-tv-kd6:36.1.5: As the Buddha was approaching Kusinārā,
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.1: the Mallians, including Roja, went out to meet him.
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.2: Roja then approached Ānanda and bowed,
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.4: “It’s noble of you to come out to meet the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.5: “I’m not doing this as a service to the Buddha, the Teaching, or the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.7: because I would get fined by the Mallians if I didn’t.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.2.8: Ānanda was disappointed with his friend.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.1: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down,
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.3: “Venerable Sir, Roja the Mallian is a well-known person.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.4: It would be of great benefit if such well-known people gained confidence in this spiritual path.
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.5: It would be good if you would inspire confidence in Roja.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.3.6: “That’s not difficult, Ānanda, for the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.1: And the Buddha suffused Roja with a mind of loving kindness, and then got up from his seat and entered a dwelling.
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.2: When Roja was suffused with loving kindness, he acted just like a young calf looking for its mother:
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.3: he went from dwelling to dwelling, from precincts to precincts, asking,
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.4: “Venerables, where is the Buddha staying, the perfected and fully Awakened One? I wish to see him.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.4.5: “In that dwelling, Roja, with the closed door. Go there quietly and slowly, enter the porch, clear your throat, and knock on the door. The Buddha will then open the door for you.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.1: Roja did what he had been told and the Buddha opened the door for him.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.2: Roja entered the dwelling, bowed, and sat down.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.3: The Buddha then gave him a progressive teaching:
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.4: talk on generosity, talk on morality, talk on heaven; and he revealed the danger, degradation, and defilement in worldly pleasures, and the benefit of renunciation. When the Buddha knew that his mind were ready, supple, without hindrances, joyful, and confident, he revealed the teaching unique to the Buddhas: suffering, its origin, its end, and the path. And just as a clean and stainless cloth takes the dye properly, so too, while he was sitting right there, Roja experienced the stainless vision of the Truth: “Anything that has a beginning has an end.” He had seen the Truth, had reached, understood, and penetrated it; he had gone beyond doubt and uncertainty, had attained to confidence, and had become independent of others in the Teacher’s instruction.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.5: And he said to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.6: “Venerable Sir, it would be good if the venerables would accept robes, almsfood, dwellings, and medicines from me, and not from others.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.7: “Roja, those who have seen the Truth with a trainee’s knowledge and vision, as you have, think like this.
pli-tv-kd6:36.5.9: But Roja, let the monks receive both from you and from others.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.1: At this time in Kusinārā there was a succession of fine meals.
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.2: Not being able to get a turn, Roja thought,
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.3: “Let me inspect the dining hall and then prepare whatever is lacking.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.4: When he did, and he saw that two things were missing:
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.5: potherbs and non-staples made with flour.
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.6: He then approached Venerable Ānanda and told what he had been thinking,
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.11: adding, “Venerable Ānanda, if I were to prepare potherbs and non-staples made with flour, would the Buddha accept it?”
pli-tv-kd6:36.6.12: “Well, Roja, let me ask the Buddha.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.1: Venerable Ānanda told the Buddha what had happened
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.2: and the Buddha said, “Allow it to be prepared, Ānanda.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.3: And Ānanda passed the message on to Roja.
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.4: The following morning Roja prepared much potherb and many non-staples made with flour and brought it to the Buddha, saying,
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.5: “Venerable Sir, please accept the potherb and the non-staples made with flour.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.6: “Well then, Roja, give it to the monks.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.8: but the monks were afraid of wrongdoing and did not accept.
pli-tv-kd6:36.7.9: The Buddha said, “Accept, monks, and eat.”
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.1: And Roja personally served much potherb and non-staple food made with flour to the Sangha of monks headed by the Buddha. When the Buddha had finished his meal, Roja sat down to one side.
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.2: The Buddha then instructed, inspired, and gladdened him with a teaching, after which he got up from his seat and left.
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.3: Soon afterwards the Buddha gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:36.8.4: “I allow you all potherbs and all non-staples made with flour.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.0: The account of the one who had gone forth when old
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Kusinārā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Ātumā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.2: At that time at Ātumā there was a monk who was previously a barber and who had gone forth when he was old.
pli-tv-kd6:37.1.3: He had two boys, sweet-voiced and articulate, who were skilled barbers, their own teacher’s trade.
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.1: The monk who had gone forth when old heard that the Buddha was coming to Ātumā,
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.2: and he said to those two boys,
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.3: “The Buddha is coming to Ātumā with a large sangha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.
pli-tv-kd6:37.2.4: Now go and get the barber equipment, and then go from house to house with a box and collect salt, oil, rice, and non-staple food. When the Buddha has arrived, we’ll make a rice-porridge drink.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.3.2: When people saw those sweet-voiced and articulate boys, they made use of their services even if they did not really want to. And they gave much in return.
pli-tv-kd6:37.3.3: Soon the boys had collected a large amount of salt, oil, rice, and non-staple food.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.1: When the Buddha eventually arrived at Ātumā,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.2: he stayed in a dwelling made of husk.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.3: The following morning that monk who had gone forth when he was old had much rice porridge prepared and he brought it to the Buddha,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.4: saying, “Venerable Sir, please accept the rice porridge.”
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.5: When Buddhas know what is going on, sometimes they ask and sometimes not; they know the right time to ask and the right time not to ask. Buddhas ask when it is beneficial, not when it is unbeneficial, for Buddhas are incapable of doing what is unbeneficial. Buddhas question the monks for two reasons:
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.6: to give a teaching or to lay down a training rule.
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.7: The Buddha then said to him,
pli-tv-kd6:37.4.8: “Where does this rice porridge come from?”
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.2: “It’s not suitable, foolish man, it’s not proper, it’s not worthy of an ascetic, it’s not allowable, it’s not to be done.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.3: How can you who have gone forth encourage others in what is unallowable for you?
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.4: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …” …
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.5: and after rebuking him he gave a teaching and addressed the monks:
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.6: “You should not encourage others to do what is unallowable for you. If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.7: And if you were previously a barber, you should not carry the barber equipment around.
pli-tv-kd6:37.5.8: If you do, you commit an offense of wrong conduct.”
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.1: When the Buddha had stayed at Ātumā for as long as he liked, he set out wandering toward Sāvatthī.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.3: he stayed in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.4: At that time in Sāvatthī much fruit had been given.
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.6: “Which fruits has the Buddha allowed and which has he not allowed?”
pli-tv-kd6:38.1.7: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.1: On one occasion seeds belonging to the Sangha had been planted on land belonging to an individual, and seeds belonging to an individual on land belonging to the Sangha.
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.3: “If seeds belonging to the Sangha have been planted on land belonging to an individual, that person should be given a share, and the produce may then be eaten.
pli-tv-kd6:39.1.4: If seeds belonging to an individual have been planted on land belonging to the Sangha, the Sangha should be given a share, and the produce may then be eaten.”
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.0: Discussion of the four great standards
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.1: At that time the monks were anxious about all sorts of matters, thinking,
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.2: “What has the Buddha allowed and what has he not allowed?”
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.3: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.4: “If I haven’t specifically prohibited something, then it’s unallowable to you if it is similar to what is unallowable and excluded from what is allowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.5: If I haven’t specifically prohibited something, then it’s allowable to you if it is similar to what is allowable and excluded from what is unallowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.6: If I haven’t specifically allowed something, then it’s unallowable to you if it is similar to what is unallowable and excluded from what is allowable.
pli-tv-kd6:40.1.7: If I haven’t specifically allowed something, then it’s allowable to you if it is similar to what is allowable and excluded from what is unallowable, .”
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.2: “Are post-midday tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or not allowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.3: Are seven-day tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or not allowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.4: Are lifetime tonics mixed with ordinary food allowable or not allowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.5: Are seven-day tonics mixed with post-midday tonics allowable or not allowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.6: Are lifetime tonics mixed with post-midday tonics allowable or not allowable?
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.7: Are lifetime tonics mixed with seven-day tonics allowable or not allowable?”
pli-tv-kd6:40.2.8: They told the Buddha and he said,
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.1: “When mixed with ordinary food, post-midday tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.2: When mixed with ordinary food, seven-day tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.3: When mixed with ordinary food, lifetime tonics are allowable before midday on the day they are received, but not after midday.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.4: When mixed with post-midday tonics, seven-day tonics are allowable after midday on the day they are received, but not after dawn.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.5: When mixed with post-midday tonics, lifetime tonics are allowable after midday on the day they are received, but not after dawn.
pli-tv-kd6:40.3.6: When mixed with seven-day tonics, lifetime tonics are allowable for seven days, but not beyond that.”
